Interface ec.meta.Tether

public interface interface Tether
A Tether is an object which represents in one objectspace an object in another objectspace. For example, a Root is a Tether that represents an in-Vat guest to an outer Java environment.

invoke(Method, Object[])
Arrange for the given method to be invoked on the Tether in a thread appropriate for it, giving it args as arguments; when the call is complete, the call to invoke returns with the return value of the call (wrapped appropriately), or throws an InvocationTargetException if the call ended in an exception.
invoke(Method, Object[], Result)
Arrange for the given method to be invoked on the Tether in a thread appropriate for it, giving it args as arguments; when the call is complete, the Tether must arrange for Result.yieldValue() or Result.yieldException (as appropriate) to be called on the given Result.

invoke 
 public abstract void invoke(Method method,
                             Object args[],
                             Result result)
Arrange for the given method to be invoked on the Tether in a thread appropriate for it, giving it args as arguments; when the call is complete, the Tether must arrange for Result.yieldValue() or Result.yieldException (as appropriate) to be called on the given Result. The result passed may be null to explicitly ignore any return value or exception. The Tether is responsible for converting the arguments into a form suitable for introduction into the target's objectspace. For example, a Root is responsible for creating the necessary Leaf objects to represent the outside world to guests.

Parameters:
theMethod - the method to call
theArgs - the arguments to pass
theResult - the channel for the result. It may be null to explicitly ignore any resultant value or exception
invoke 
 public abstract Object invoke(Method method,
                               Object args[]) throws BadInvokeException, InvocationTargetException
Arrange for the given method to be invoked on the Tether in a thread appropriate for it, giving it args as arguments; when the call is complete, the call to invoke returns with the return value of the call (wrapped appropriately), or throws an InvocationTargetException if the call ended in an exception. The Tether is responsible for converting the arguments into a form suitable for introduction into the target's objectspace. For example, a Root is responsible for creating the necessary Leaf objects to represent the outside world to guests.

Parameters:
theMethod - the method to call
theArgs - the arguments to pass
Returns:
the result of the underlying method call, wrapped appropriately
Throws: BadInvokeException
thrown if there was a problem with the arguments or process of invocation
Throws: InvocationTargetException
thrown if the underlying method ended abruptly with an exception
